The object of the game is to guide the rocketball into your opponent's goal, but you can't touch the rocketball directly. Instead, you must place vortices and other obstacles in front of the rocketball to alter its course, guiding it to your objective.

Gameplay has a strong emphasis on tile placement and modification. The game comes with many variants and alternate game versions as well.
categories: Maze, Print & Play, Puzzle, Science Fiction, Sports

name: REM
description:
REM, "The First Card Game for the Computer Age"

From the box:
"A fun and easy way to learn 17 commonly used computer terms. Players sharpen their memory as they form programs by matching terms from the popular BASIC computer programming language. Competition intensifies as opponents wipe out each others programs and damage each others disks. Definitions, with questions and answers, are provided for those who wish to learn more about the terms. Miniature computer paper is included for keeping score. (The terms are used by Apple, TRS-80, Commodore, and most other fine computers.)"

A copy of this game resides in the Smithsonian Institution.

name: Monotony
description:
This is one of the more original Monopoly parodies I've come across.
Monotony relies on the stereotyping of a housewife’s lifestyle for its entertainment value. In Monotony, the goal of each Homemaker is to acquire more items (Dust Balls, Grocery Sacks, Husbands, Kids and Pets) than any of the opponents. Successful Homemakers may qualify during the game to wear the sacred Spoon-Through-the-Head! The rules are a riot to read.

name: Yukk!
description:
Yukk! is a dinner simulation. The parents have prepared a variety of "yucky" foods and the players are competing to see who can clear their plate first. The mechanics are somewhat deterministic, and the game seems better suited to younger players.

The basic game play involves discarding a food card if possible. If not, the player can play a food card on another person, or play a special card such as "switch plates" or "feed the dog."
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Print & Play
publishers: (Web published), Interactivities Ink, The Game Crafter, LLC

name: WaveLength
description:
WaveLength is a game where you predict how friends and family will respond to common questions about people, entertainment, sports and everyday items.

WaveLength questions have many possible answers! Each game card contains 4 of the most popular and 3 lesser known wild card answers.

Only the card holder knows the answers on the card. It's up to the card holder to select the answer that’s most likely to be chosen by the other players. But players must choose shrewdly because the more uncommon the answer, the higher the point value.

The Objective is to be the first player to reach 100 points; card holder and players receive points for matching the card holder’s answer. All-match bonuses and blind doubles make the gameplay even more exciting.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Sports, Word Game

name: Karnak
description:
"One of the seven wonders of the world"

This one to six-player strategy game uses the floor plan of the hypo style room of the temple of Amun at Karnak as its board, roughly 16×5. Stacking is involved --I have no idea beyond that. Players can form teams, and two players can even collaborate in solving the solitaire game.

Check out the beautiful board at Pharao-Brettspiele's home page.

name: Column
description: A weird spin off of Backgammon. Each player starts with 12 playing pieces on their side of the board. The first player to move all 12 of their playing pieces across the board and off the other side wins. Moves are made by rolling 3 dice. After you roll you decide which die determines which column you can move a piece in and use the other two dice to determine how far by subtracting the smaller number from the larger number. Triples and Double are a big help.

name: Headlines
description: Headlines is a Monopoly clone quiz game, in which players try to compose tabloid headlines from stories read to them. Whilst a sand timer runs down, roll & move round the track, stopping on categories like Sports, Law, Business, Lifestyle. A card with 4 stories is taken for that category and one of the stories read out to the player. Using key words from the story, the player declares the headline. Getting it correct boosts your paper's circulation. On Photo-scoop cards, you must identify the celebrity. There are also Extra! cards for gain/loss and other players may Grab the headline in question. The game has a quarter-board with 2 tracks, the inner for the Sundays, and 560 question cards, the stories drawn from British papers in the 90s.

name: Succession
description: A game based on the kings and queens of England. Players collect runs of monarchs in date sequence of 3 cards or more, and of the same House. A hand is won by laying out all of your cards, or holding all 4 chance cards, or 3 chance and the Cromwell card. Players tally up minus points for cards remaining in hand, and anyone with more than 100 points is eliminated. The last player with less than 100 points wins.

name: Z-Chess
description:
Z-Chess is a cross between the game of GLE'X and conventional chess. Two GLE'X boards put together - overlapping in the middle - make up the playing field. Conventional chess pieces - with the addition of a second Queen - are used to play the game. The goal, just like in the ancient game, is to capture the opponent's King. The strategy is similar as well, however, the nature of the Z-Chess board requires the pieces to move differently. The Rooks are more powerful than the Queens, resulting from the way they move. A single Rook attacks all 77 "squares" when other pieces are removed from the board.
The "squares" actually are circles at the intersections, same way as on the GLE'X board.

name: Action Test
description:
With the 3rd player acting as referee, 2 players have 7 action cards and compete to select the correct one which matches one of 41 target cards, e.g. the letter on the postman, the flower for the lady. First to get it right takes the target card, get it wrong and you forfeit the target card.
You win if you get the most target cards, but automatically lose if you play a dumb match, e.g. use the fire extinguisher on a person, fail to use the fire truck on the burning house.
The ref deals the target cards and adjudicates, then plays the winner and so on. Rules in German and English. A good enough speed game, the sort of thing Reinhard Staupe could modernize nicely.

Published earlier under the name "Shock" with different pictures, but people had issues with playing "terrorist", "machine gun" and similar cards.

name: Lost World
description: Based on Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s novel.

name: Nieznaika on the Moon
description: Based on the novel by Nikolai Nosov and on cartoon TV-series.

name: King Tut
description: A Jenga/Mikado variant, de-construct a wooden pyramid without it falling and you losing, reconstruct a triangular structure and win. A surprisingly large wooden pyramid is made of 30 wooden pieces resting on a very solid wooden board, making the box really, really heavy.

name: Little League Lunatics
description: After the Little League game the players participate in a brawl. You control cards representing the different kids who have different skills who then fight it out with hands and weapons. Last player standing wins.

name: Bloody Mary
description: Cards & dice create a game themed on cocktail drinking. The rules include a recipe for a Bloody Mary. Published in an L-shaped box.

name: Irono Ofubi
description: A tricky game with colour, players use 30 round and 30 oval pieces, placed on a board showing faces/masks in a theatrical Japanese style.

name: Slapstick
description:
Slapstick! is a game in which players move their pieces around a board in an attempt to simulate the slapstick comedies of 1930s Hollywood. The game represents these events, e.g. slipping on banana skins, encountering crazy gorillas, pie fights, etc., in the form of cards.

Each player starts from a corner of the board (which is divided into rooms) and with 2 cards of each type of comedic act in his or her hand. Going in turns, they roll a die to move their tokens and attempt to get rid of their cards. Certain acts, such as those for pie fights, can be passed to players whose tokens are within range. Others can only be passed to players whose tokens are in the same room or are laid down as traps (a player whose token passes over them has to pick them up). The player who empties his or her hand of cards wins the game.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: The Scotch Whisky Game
description: The object is to become Scotland's most powerful Whisky baron, by producing the country's most prestigious brands. Players vie for control of Scotland's leading blended, deluxe, and malt whisky, answer questions on Scottish history, myth, and culture, and attempt to avoid the numerous hazards of the whisky industry.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Das Zeitungsspiel
description:
Players gradually complete the layout of the front page of the local newspaper Nurnberger Nachrichten. The tiles are in various squared shapes and are placed and moved on the grid according to their topic, Politics, Sport, etc., which affects how each player scores. Graphic design by Franz Vohwinkel.

The game is similar to Karl-Heinz Schmiel's Kunst StÃ¼cke, but has somewhat different components and a few important rules differences.

name: Largo Winch
description:
(Based on Tilsit's page: http://www.tilsit.fr/fiches_jeux/largo.php)

After the assassination of his father, the 26-year old Largo Winch finds himself at the head of a ten billion dollar empire, the W Group. The Adriatic Commission, a secret organization with apparently unlimited power, does not like this and decides to replace him with a more "accommodating" figure head. All blows are allowed: physical elimination, dismantlement of the W Group, hostile take-over, criminal frame-up, kidnapping of his loved ones, etc.

Largo must fight on all fronts, investigate and foil all attempts on him. He can only count on Simon, his childhood friend, Joy, his seductive bodyguard, Sullivan, his director-general, and Kerensky, an ex-KGB high-tech specialist.

This board game of high adventure will keep all fans of the TV series (itself based on the graphic novels created by Jean Van Hamme and drawn by Philippe Francq) on the edge of their seats.
categories: Adventure, Comic Book / Strip, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Quick Quiz?
description: A plastic box is shaken and 3 letters and one subject are randomly selected. Players have 2 minutes to write down as many words starting with the 3 selected letters, as long as they deal with the selected subject.

name: Countermoves Generic Microgame Engine
description:
The CGME Core Rules are the basic building blocks that could be used to make a Microgame. Think of them as atoms. With just these core rules you will not be able to play much. What you can do with them though is build up Gameworlds that take the CGME Core Rules and fill in the details of the game setting you want to play.

The Gameworlds are the source documents that will add the detail to the Core Rule's atomic structure. They will describe things like a worlds terrain, the units available, their strengths and weaknesses, the climate, special rules that modify combat resolution, new rules that cover things like horse back ridding, vector space ship movement, and just how to handle a Vogon star destroyer that has wandered into your Medieval Fantasy realm.

By building off the same Core Rules and by using the Gameworlds you have created, or have been created by others, you can then build up Gamesets to cover the specific events to play out. For example, by using the CGME Core Rules coupled with the CGME Space Gameworld you could build a Gameset to play interstellar battles, trade wars across colonial star systems, early 1970's Soviet vs. US orbital conflicts, and many more.

If a Gameworld does not cover all the details you need to play out your event, you are free to haul off and add in what you need, modify what is there and hopefully make it available so others can use it.

CGME is freely available in Volume 1 Issue 1 of Countermoves

name: Karl May-Spiel
description: Karl May Spiel is a game rather intended for the children. The principle is classic. The players are in confrontation in a running where it is necessary to be the first one in the arrival, having found two identical objects and having crossed different obstacles. The originality of the game lives in the die. In fact, there is no die, because the players determine their advance by a shot to the elastic representing archery. It is thus the fitness and not the fate that leads the game, but for some players, it is about the same thing!

name: Gamblers Golf
description: The game consists of a playing board layout of a typical 18-hole championship golf course. A tee marker is moved along the course to indicate the number of strokes (rolls of the dice) a player has taken to "hole out." Twenty-five chips are given to each player at the start of the game, and these are given up as a player fails to keep their ball on track, eventually being won by whoever has the low score for the game. Also included are 3 dice and a pad of golf scorecards. The score is kept for each player as in golf.

name: Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants: Hell Card Expansion #2 â Anger Management
description:
Yet another 40 cards for WHAT. The WHAT: Hell expansion board is also required.

Expands:

Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants

name: Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants: Hell Card Expansion #1 â Alone
description:
Forty additional cards for WHAT (the WHAT: Hell expansion board is required as well).

Expands:

Worlds of Heroes & Tyrants

name: Dice Deck
description:
This game consists of four dice and a deck of special cards. They come in three suits (blue, green, red) and range from 2 to 12 in value. The frequencies vary (one each of 2, 3, 11, and 12; two each of 4, 5, 9, 10 and three each of 6, 7, and 8).

There are rules for ten games. Two family games: Cancellation and Dice Deck Rummy, two children's games: Give And Take and Crazy Dice, two casino games (you will have to supply the betting chips): Three Card Down and Make My Point, two strategy games: Pathfinder and Admiral, and two solitary games: Dice Deck Bingo and Stack 'Em Up.

To give but one example, in Dice Deck Rummy you are dealt 8 cards. On your turn, you draw a card from the stock or the top discard. You then roll two dice. You can play any sets of the number rolled (two or more cards of that value), or any runs (three or more same color cards that follow each other in sequence) that end or begin with the number rolled (counting the dice as an extra card). Finally you discard. You can also freely increase played sets and runs on your turn. First player to go out scores the total value remaining in the other players' hands.

Dice Deck is similar to the Deck of Dice

name: Weed Wars: On Higher Ground
description: The object of the game is for the first person to make a million dollars by growing, harvesting and trafficking different strains of marijuana. It is a highly interactive game, giving players the opportunity to hinder another opponent's financial progress. This game does not endorse the use, sale or cultivation of marijuana, however is a fantasy of a different life, lived by some and to others only ever read about in the papers and seen on TV. This is the first of a series of patented games brought to the world by Nyte Tyme Enterprises Inc., with the idea of representing alternative lifestyles in play, and offering an opportunity to be someone that you either never wanted to be, or never had the opportunity to become. "Weed Wars - On Higher Ground" is a factual representation of the trials and tribulations of characters involved in all aspects of the marijuana industry and culture.
mechanics: Commodity Speculation, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Dinosaur Hunters!
description:
Using a spinner to randomly select which action you must take this turn, each player attempts to assemble their jigsaw puzzle depicting a fossilized dinosaur.

Actions direct the player to buy, trade or draw a "bone" (puzzle piece) or take a card of a random event deck.

name: Criss-Cross
description:
A two player word game.

Each player has a collection of letter tiles, and a screened-off area to make words in a 5x5 grid as in a crossword puzzle.

Rules are in German, French, and (I believe) Swedish.

name: A Racing Game!
description:
Be the first to cross the finish line in this fast-paced game of luck and strategy.

Roll the dice as many as three times and save the best combination that moves your racer as far down the track as possible. If you roll a flat tire on your third roll, you lose your turn. If you cut off another player, that player loses a turn.

A Racing Game! helps children learn basic strategy skills and develop social skills by following rules and taking turns.

name: An Evening of Murder: Fatal Reunion
description:
One in the series of "Max Haines Invites You To An Evening of Murder (tm)" party games. Plays like the popular "How to Host a Murder" series. This particular edition is "Fatal Reunion." Being a more recent issue in the line, it includes less colorful components than the Canada Games editions. From the box...

Crime Scene: When Norma Ashby heard they were closing Lakeside High School and tearing it down, she was devastated. She, one of the few alumni left in town, was on a mission. She would save the school. She decided to have a reunion and convince her old classmates to help her purchase Lakeside High.

This was the high school reunion weekend. The 'get re-acquainted' party the night before was a great success. In fact so much so that the eight of you and Norma decided to meet at the Lakeside Greasy Spoon before going to the 60's, 70's 'Rock 'n' Roll' costume party. Norma never made it that night.

Norma had said she would save Lakeside High or die trying. And, that is exactly what happened. Norma Ashby was found dead in her home. She had been shot to death.

The Suspects:

Debbie Rowe: A devoted wife and proud mother. Driven by her competitive nature. How far would she go to be number one?

Blake Walker: He is a soap star. An 'idol' who has it all. A beautiful wife, wonderful children...what more could he ask for?

Mary-Lou Potts: A successful businesswoman with a razor sharp mind and a troubled past. Left Lakeside and vowed never to return. Was attending the reunion a cover...for murder?

Doug Griffin: An ex-football player. Spoiled and reckless, he hates rules and regulations. Was his next play "unsportsmanlike conduct"?

Dr. Veronica Hardy: A psychiatrist and marriage counselor. Haunted by a past she tries to keep secret. Was she all psyched out?

Dr. Wayne Hardy: Veronica's husband and business partner. He is attractive, friendly, and self-assured. He and Veronica have it made. Would he risk it all for revenge?

Wendy Larose: A high priced Madam. She is quick-witted with loose morals. Would she do anything, or anyone, to get what she wanted?

Randy Whalen: Police Officer for Lakeside's finest. He was a forceful personality, not to be crossed. Has crime and violence become a part of his nature?
publishers: Irwin Toy Ltd., Pentalpha Game Corporation

name: Life of the Party: The Coffeehouse Murder
description:
Milton Bradley produced 8 mystery party/role-playing games (in the vein of “How to Host a Murder”) beginning in 1987. They were published as "Life of the Party" games; four mysteries and four murders. These are also copyright Jamie Swise Games—the designer of the games, who produced several other titles (and many, if not all, of these) a few years earlier.

Episode: The Coffeehouse Murder

Folk singer Jeremy Swain was found dead in an apartment above the Gate of Fate Coffeehouse. He had just finished a two night engagement at the club before embarking on his first national tour. It was very uncool what got laid on poor Jeremy. Like, it was a stone drag. Dig. Invite some faces over to the crib, make a scene, and riff on who did the cat up.*


Translation within


The Time: August 16, 1958

The Place: The North Beach area of San Francisco

Patty Farb: Department store heiress with too much money and too much time on her hands. She often gave money to struggling artists she felt showed promise. Patty had affairs with most of the performers at the club and once fell especially hard for Swain. She also gave her money to many causes and was once, for a short time, a member of the American Communist Party. She attended a party for Swain that evening and claimed she was with one of her artist friends at the time of his death.

Art Fez: The bongo playing comedian who opened the show for Swain and doubled as the M.C.. Fez was active in the labor movement in the late 1940's and at that time a good friend of Swain. Fez was called before the House Un-American Activities Committee (HUAC) While he was cleared of any "wrong-doing", he was black-listed from the clubs and was playing his first gig in four years. He did attend Swain's party but left early. He stated that he was searching the streets for a restaurant that served purple gelatin at the time of Swain's death.

Barney Fawn: Forty year-old club owner and amateur UFO watcher. Fawn claimed to have had encounters with alien beings and believes some of the acts he hires are the next closest things. He would loan struggling artists moderate sums of money and then have them pay him back by playing his club for peanuts. He did not attend the party, choosing to remain downstairs counting the night's receipts instead.

Teresa Wilcox: Was Swain's live-in but was not sharing the apartment during Jeremy's current engagement. They had been having "marital" problems of late. Wilcox also served as Swain's back-up singer but did not perform at the Gate of Fate. She attended the party but was unclear of her whereabouts at the time of his death.

Rocky Tuttle: Young and aggressive loan officer of a small bank. Tuttle was making the scene often in the past few months. Although he was as square as they come, Tuttle and Swain struck up a close friendship. He did not attend the party and was vague about his movements around the time of the crime.

Del Finney: Swain's business manager and owner of a dry cleaning store. He was a big force behind Swain's success and was a hard working as any manager of a folk act could be. Finney was not at the party. He left right after the show to make final preparations for Swain's next date.

Natalie Corvus: She was a chronic club hanger-on who fancied herself a talented singer. She would invariably come on stage every amateur night and belt Gregorian chants at the top of her lungs. Natalie was often seen outside the club in Swain's company and it was well known that Teresa found that fact unbearable. Natalie was at the party but left after a boisterous argument with Wilcox about the former's singing or lack of singing talents. She claims she was star gazing at the time of death.

Fran Fern: Fran was the manager/bartender at the Gate of Fate. She was briefly married to Swain during the lean years. Active in many causes, she once lobbied to have the raisin declared the national fruit. She stayed in the club to clean-up and did not attend the party.

Game Includes:
Full Plot Scenario
Character Biographies
Recorded Introduction
24 Clues
Solution

name: Beyond the Stars
description: Children can travel through space and score points accomplishing missions.

name: Mysteries by Vincent: Lynched in Lucre Valley
description:
How to Host a Murder styled party game. No audio comes with these games, just clue booklets and party planner.

LYNCHED IN LUCRE VALLEY -or- Who Rigged the Rig?

It's July, 1952, and the oil industry has been booming in Alberta, Canada since the end of WWII. New oil reserves have been discovered just as fast as wildcatters can set up rigs and drill. As a result, new oil and oilfield service companies have been springing up like Alberta winter wheat. One such company is Drye Holle Drilling, founded by Mr. Dryesdale "Drye" Holle of Lucre Valley. And tonight, you've been invited to attend the company's First Annual Safety Award Dinner, in honor of Drye Holle Drilling's remarkable safety record. And of course, the affair will be catered by the local Crude Cafe.

Now the real question remains: Will Drye Holle Drilling have an outstanding safety record for a second year in a row? In any case, one thing is certain, murder would definitely mar that record . . .

Your Dinner Companions Include:

Tarra "Tar" Sanze is a sassy secretary who mans the front lines of Drye Holle Drilling. Known for her smarts as well as her savvy, she's a tornado on the typewriter and a dervish when it comes to dictation. Pretty as well as proficient, she's had more than her share of suitors, but the oil industry remains the love of her life. She dresses to fit the occasion - pants or skirts for trips to the field and dazzling dresses for dinner.

Derek Hand is the dashing Drilling Manager at Drye Holle Drilling, a company Derek has worked for since he and Drye returned from the War in Europe. Hard working and an industry expert, Derek's loyalty to the company is legendary. Because he's constantly on call, he prefers to wear casual work clothes.

Madame Mae Kittup is an exotic beauty from the Ukraine, a gypsy woman whose psychic powers include telling the future via her magic pysankas, or Ukrainian Easter eggs. Sultry and mysterious, Madame Mae is employed by Drye Holle Drilling to locate oil reserves far beneath the Earth's surface. Yet she attributes her great gift to her grandmother, and prefers to dress in the clothing of her native land.

Denver Driller is a rich and rugged oilman from the States, whose business frequently brings him to Canada, where he plans to reap the rewards of the country's bountiful resources. A world traveler, he's charming and charismatic, and a favorite among the locals. He dresses to suit the occasion, with a wardrobe that ranges from designer suits to dungarees.

Olivia "Ol" Barrinesse could be described in three simple words: rich, refined and ravishing. Originally from Calgary, she's the daughter of the late Brigham Barrinesse, from whom she inherited her wealth, as well as her independent and highly profitable oil company, Brigham Oil. Ol is always dressed in the height of fashion, famous for her foreign shopping sprees and her bounty of baubles.

Andre P. Renure is a bold businessman who provides a valuable service to the oilfield consumer by running Lucre Valley's only general store and restaurant, the Crude Cafe. A Frenchman from Quebec, he came to the West after the War, hoping to amass a fortune from his vocational ventures. Shrewd and sophisticated, his suits are the latest of fifties fashions.

Beulah "Beu" T. Kween is a beaming beauty from the heart of bovine country, who was raised on a cattle ranch in southern Alberta. Having won more than her share of beauty contests, everyone says her future is bright, that she'll be married with a house full of kids before she can say "baby boom." Flirtatious and fun-loving, she currently works as a waitress at the Crude Cafe, where she earns enough money to keep her wardrobe stocked with delectable dresses.

Royal T. Ohhner is an Alberta cattle rancher whose range reaches far across some big beefy underground oil reserves - oil reserves that are leased to and drilled by Drye Holle Drilling. Thus Royal often jokes about raising both crude and cattle, which have proven to be real cash cows for him. A real grass roots kind of guy, he's never been one to steer away from hard work. He wears nothing but Western attire.

This mystery game features a Western Canadian setting. (If you've never seen Calgary and the Canadian Rockies, then you've never really lived!) So, of course, we used some classic characters that you might find in that neck of the bush -- the Frenchman from Quebec, the Ukranian woman and her psyankas (decorated eggs), a cattle rancher and the people in the oil industry. Of course, there's also a mention of playing hockey.

Besides all that, it's set in the early 1950s, which provides so much opportunity for costumes, as well as setting the mood. People can dress either 1940s or 1950s style, and you can easily play music from both decades.

All and all, it's a fun romp, with the same lunacy and ludicrousness as the rest of our mystery games. Watch out for the surprise twist at the end!

name: Jamie Swise Mystery Games: Murder by Proxy
description:
Early (predecessor?) parlor/play-acting game of hosting a murder/mystery. There were at least six games in the Jamie Swise line, some of which were incorporated into the Milton Bradley Life of the Party line of mystery games. This one...

Why did a nice lady like Mary Wrightwood suddenly stop publishing her weekly gossip rag and begin building a virtual empire, producing closet pornography? We think it is a question which needs answering. And if that burning question doesn't compel you, you might like to figure out who murdered her.

The case of characters is indeed curious: a right-wing megalomaniac, the cold-blooded co-publisher, a pompous author, a flower child, the degenerate son, an immensely virile handy man, the town's mayor and only plumber, and Mary's bible thumping ex-best friend.

The time is March, 1968. Feelin' groovy?

name: Equality
description:
Almost identical to Scrabble, but with numbers forming equations rather than letters forming words.

"The game is played with tiles numbered 0 to 12 and tiles showing mathematical signs and parentheses. Each tile has a score (except the equality sign and parentheses). The most valuable numeral is 7 (because it has the least options for making an equation that equals 12 or less) and the most valuable signs are division and multiplication (again because there are less equations involving these operations that equal 12 or less). Like scrabble, squares on the board can increase your score, whether an individual tile or for the entire equation."
Source: http://www.dicemaestro.com/vintage-games/retroactive.asp

name: 5 in a Row Challenge
description: 5 in a Row Challenge is not just a game of connecting 5 game pieces in a row. With the ability to capture your opponent's pieces and move pieces after all 25 pieces have been placed on the board, connecting 5 in a row becomes a fun, exciting, and satisfying challenge.

name: Swedish Roulette
description: Swedish Roulette is an exciting version of the Big Casino game that will provide all the drama and suspense of the Monte Carlo original. 8 small balls, one of which is red, are placed in the center of the bowl. A player then spins the top. As the top spins, the body of it will hurl the balls knocking them about in the bowl. Action continues until the spinning top settles down. Scores are totaled by adding the numbers above the balls that have remained in a recessed spot along the outer edge of the bowl. The red ball scores double.

name: Phenomenon: the Extra Sensory Party
description:
A party game which is to be planned ahead of time, somewhat like a murder mystery party. Only this time, players are exploring their psychic powers. Players are to bring a personal object concealed in a plain paper bag for psycho-transmissions or something like that.

When the game begins (after a warm-up period), players simply move along a board and partake in activities written on cards. These usually involve some pseudo-science along the lines of the doctors from Ghostbusters.

Game even includes a quartz crystal.

name: Das Revolutionsspiel von 1791
description:
Das Revolutionsspiel von 1791 is a thematic implementation of the 16th century Game of Goose. The game board is illustrated with scenes of the French Revolution in the late 18th century: the pictures from the starting point to the end point follow the course of the event.

Players take turns to roll the dice and move their tokens according to the total of the dice. Landing on certain spaces could mean advancing the token further up the path, losing turns, or going back to the starting point. If a token lands on a chicken space, it gets to double its move (and double it again if it still lands on a chicken space).

The game ends when a player's token lands exactly on the end point, making him or her the winner. If the movement would overshoot the end point, the token has to backtrack the excess amount.

name: Nimbali
description:
Nimbali is set in the African bush. The game board shows four watering holes, each of which is assigned to a player. Each watering hole is filled with 9 blue wooden raindrops. Five animals (giraffe, cheetah, lion, zebra, and rhino) are placed on the board at the various watering holes. Players throw a single oversized die to determine the action of each move: five of the die faces depict the five animal hide patterns of the animal figures, and the sixth die face shows a blue raindrop. When the player's roll brings up one of the fur patterns, the player moves the corresponding animal clockwise around the board to the next watering hole. When the die roll shows the raindrop symbol, all players remove one raindrop from his watering hole for every animal that is standing at that player's watering hole at that time.

The winner is the player who feeds the most thirsty animals by being the first to run out of raindrops.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Environmental
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Diangle
description:
Diangle is a race game of luck and strategy.

Players race to be the first to complete levels 1 through 6 and back again, in order on their triangular gameboard. Each player has a set of 6 custom dice. Each die is different, having a different face marked in red. Players can complete a numbered level by rolling 3 dice with that number, and then can move on and try to complete the next level. To win, you'll have to move fast, as you work on the completion of 3 levels a time. The red numbers complete their level all by themselves, giving you the chance to race ahead.

name: Pferdemist
description:
Horses leave "apples" as they wander in the pasture, the farmers collect the "apples" hoping to use the manure in their gardens, the rabbits try to eat the farmers' vegetables and the hunters try to stop the rabbits. The first farmer to score 50 points by growing vegetables and collecting manure wins.

The game is played on a board with a 16 by 16 grid, divided up into four 8 by 8 fields (i.e. 4 chess boards put together). Each player controls a horse that roams around leaving manure in the field. The player's farmer wants to collect the manure to use in his field to grow his vegetables. Each player also controls a rabbit which will try to eat the other players' vegetables and a hunter that tries to keep the rabbit away. In the game the pieces have moves similar to chess pieces. The horse moves like a knight (of course), the farmer like the king, the rabbit like a bishop and the hunter like a rook. Players receive 2 points for each vegetable grown and 1 point for each bucket of manure.

The game may be played solitaire, by 2 or 4 players or by teams.

name: White Collar Blues
description: Experience a day in the office job from hell! Make sales telephone calls, gossip and back stab your colleagues, and perform all sorts of menial tasks (secret or otherwise) all in order to collect Brownie points to please the boss. The day culminates when you must eventually see the boss for your review. The player with the most Brownie points at the end of the day is the winner!
mechanics: Hand Management, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Trigon Chess & Checkers
description: Chess and Checkers for 3 players using a "trigonal" board.

name: Gopher Greens
description: A golf game in which club swings are simulated by drawing from a deck of cards. The card drawn tells the player how far their shot went and what club type they will be swinging next stroke. All of the standard types of golf variants (skins, rabbit, etc.) can also be played with this game.

name: 77 Sunset Strip
description:
Players take on the roles of detectives searching for clues to a murder in a run down motel.

Once they collect enough information from the tenants and piece together the Motive, Weapon and Time of the crime, they may make an accusation.

The first player to make a successful accusation wins the game.
categories: Exploration, Memory, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Murder/Mystery, Puzzle

name: A Kin to Win
description:
Based on the game show of the same name, A Kin to Win is a combination trivia/connect 4 game.

One player acts as Master of Ceremonies (MC) and alternates asking questions of two players (or teams).

Players first indicate, on a 7X7 grid, where they would like their answer. They may choose any square to extend their own marker's lines or to block their opponents. The unknown element of the game is that the MC does not tell the players whether the answers they gave are right or wrong until 14 questions have been asked. When a player (or team) thinks that they have four correct answers in a row, they shout "I win!". If they are right, the collect $500; if wrong, they are told which answers are wrong and play passes to their opponents.

The game is played over a number of rounds... the team with the most money wins.

name: Year of the Lord
description:
The playing board contains two tracks.

The external track represents the weeks of the Church Calendar. It also has five "bullseye" spaces... special targets (such as Christmas and Easter) that must be obtained.

The internal track represents the 'Days of the Saints' and is used to complete the game.

Players roll dice and move around the track, trying to get five markers on the different "bullseye" spaces. Once they have completed this portion of the game, their markers are moved to the inner track to begin racing for the finish. Movement may be clockwise or counterclockwise, however once you reach another player's token you may only move further by the same number of spaces as it took you to get there (allowing for some blocking strategy).

The inner track is a simple race game. It contains 42 squares to the finish box.

The first player to move all five of his tokens through the inner track past the finish space is the winner.

name: Upbid
description:
Upbid is billed as a game of Business Strategy and Risk.

The principle component to the game are 48 cards with two strategies, A and B, cross referenced with the roll of a pair of dice, and a payoff. For example:

STRATEGY A: 2-7: -10$, 8-10: +100$, 11-12: +1250$
STRATEGY B: +300$, -100$, -120$

In the basic game players take turns revealing the cards, choosing a strategy, and rolling to see the gain or loss. In the slightly more advanced game each player is allowed to buy partial information on a card, by rolling a single die before committing to a strategy. In the example above partial information costs 90$, and if you bought it then rolled a 6 you would be more inclined to choose strategy A.

In the advanced game players take turns revealing cards, and auctioning them off to the other players who then play them against the auctioning player, rather than a bank. Additionally each card has a set indicator, and when you collect six cards in a set you can turn them in for 500$ from each player.

name: Das Steiff-Spiel
description:
Steiff are famous makers of high quality Teddy Bears. This game has cut-outs of bears moving around the board, as well as a genuine miniature Steiff moves up a side track.

Ages 6 and up

name: Quartiers Chauds
description:
A magazine game from Jeux et StratÃ©gie #37.

It takes place in Paris, a Paris you wouldn't know...

Each player plays a gang trying to engage in racketeering, prostitution, theft, and drugs while avoiding the police and trying to get rid of the other gangs.

name: Macross: Space Fold
description:
Complexity rating of '4' on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).

"Game of Space Combat in Macross'

Strategic space combat game based off the science fiction anime tv show. One player tries protecting Macross (aka SDF-1 in the US Robotech) from the other player, who plays the alien Zentran (aka Zendraedi in the US Robotech).

"Macross Life" is bonus game in the box. This game represent private life of Valkyrie pilots. Players will compete to pick up girls.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Urusei Yatsura: Koi wa Utsurigi
description:
Complexity level 3 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

"The game of Girl Hunt in Urusei Yatsura"

Based off the wacky love/comedy science fiction anime/manga series Urusei Yatura.

The male characters from Urusei Yatsura attempt to date girls. It takes into account your characters current levels of power, mind ('mental'), and power; you send the girls love letters and go on dates with them to try to get them to like you. Includes a ton of cards for the characters and events.

Japanese intensive for both the rules and components.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Tokimeki Memorial 2 Game of Life ('Jinsei Game')
description: Loosely based off Milton Bradley's Game of Life, but it's really a different game. There's now dating squares, which is perhaps why the box says its for ages 15 and up. Includes 11 cute miniatures representing the 11 girls from the videogame.

name: King of the Anthill
description:
King of the Anthill was published in Intruder magazine #6. Can Eric, the Intruder, rescue the other humans before the they are trapped forever in this alternate dimension?

One player controls the interdimensional creatures trying to capture the humans and drag them deep into the 'Anthill'. The other player takes the role of the humans and attempts to escape from the top of the hill, battling native creatures along the way.

To win, the Human player must get all three humans to the top of the hill. The Native player wins if he can prevent this from happening.

name: Orguss: Orguroid
description:
Complexity level 2 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

The Game of Battles in the Orguss

Based off the mecha anime "Orguss", this game takes place on the ground, over mountainous terrian. Includes counters and 3 single sided mounted maps.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Craters of Tharsis
description:
Craters of Tharsis is a two-player boardgame published in Buck Rogers magazine #3. It is based, in part, on the novel Hammer of Mars (also published by TSR). One player takes the role of the NEO freedom fighters, the other plays the omnipresent RAM.

The game includes a mapsheet of the area (where the battles for Mars take place), 6 pages of rules (covering basic initiative, movement, and attack phases), and one sheet of cut-out counters.

Victory points are given to each player for destroying (or stealing, for the NEO player) enemy units. The game ends when all NEO troops are killed or all RAM Krait fighters have left the map. The player with the most points wins.

name: The Gauntlet
description:
The Gauntlet is a two-player boardgame that was published in Buck Rogers magazine #1.

One player is Anatoly Karpov, the renegade Russian general who has stolen the Masterlink, a space based weapon satellite. The other player is Col. Anthony 'Buck' Rogers, America's greatest pilot.

The game contains a map, 8 pages of rules, 106 cut-apart counters, and player ship displays.

The U.S. player wins if Masterlink is destroyed. The Soviet player wins if Buck Rogers is killed and Kharkov survives, no matter how badly Masterlink is otherwise damaged. Special tournament victory conditions are also provided based on varying levels of victory.
publishers: Buck Rogers / Dille Family Trust, Tactical Studies Rules (TSR)

name: Space Cobra
description:
Part of Bandai's Game for Adult "IF" series.

Game for Adult meaning aimed at older players, not anything with objectionable content.

"If" just refers to the their gimmick of setting up each game in the series as a "What if... (insert game scenario)"

Complexity 3.5 on Bandai's 1-7 scale (1=easiest)

Based off the late 60s science fiction sexy action anime. This is more of a role playing/boardgame mix than anything, but it really is unique and tough to explain. There is a flip-book that has various locations depicted to use as a board, but the game does unfold like a dungeon-crawl RPG despite taking place in the far future.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Monster Jam Truck Game
description: Monster Jam Truck Game: In this fast-paced never-before-seen game, kids can re-create the rugged challenges and outrageous antics they see on Monster Jam® television shows. This is the first board game to feature the massively popular Monster Trucks. The game features Hot Wheels licenses, including He-Man and Gravedigger, the hottest Monster Truck around. Cards guide the players through the jumps and stunts of the game.

name: Flash Fighter
description: Science fiction mecha fighting game. The object is to be the last player alive. There are weapon, defense, support, and special cards. You power up your robot with those cards and try to defeat everyone else's robots.

name: Level Up!
description: A Fantasy card game, with art by the writer/artist of "Dragon Half". You play monsters, friends, and items. You defeat monsters to gain experience, and when you reach 4th level, you can then fight the final boss to win the game.

name: Kimagure Angels
description: A fantasy card game about a groups/parties of characters that have been given a second chance at life. The players play good or evil angels, who grant parties of adventurers a second chance at life. You try to have them finish quests to support your cause.

name: Monster Maker School Excursion
description:
Alternate title: Monster Maker Shuugaku Ryoukou

Side-story to the main Monster Maker series, this is the 3rd in a series of card games featuring the Monster Maker characters in a still-fantasy high school setting.

In this game, everyone goes on school vacations. You need to find someone to go together with; certain characters get along better with each other. You need to find an airplane that goes to the destination card you want to go to. Going on vacations to exotic places are worth the most points; vacations to the Dark Land are negative points.

name: Super Nova: Event Horizon
description:
Event Horizon is the long awaited expansion set for the science fiction card game Super Nova.

The supplement features 60 all new cards, including two new alien races, plus new ships, planets, and specials. There's also an all new type of card, the Event card. Event cards are played during the Event phase (a new phase that occurs right after the Draw phase) and include things like Mass Insanity, Floater Migration, Temporal Storm, and Emperor's Birthday.

Note, however, that this is not a stand-alone expansion. You need a copy of Super Nova.

Expands:

Super Nova
categories: Card Game, Economic, Expansion for Base-game, Political, Science Fiction
mechanics: Hand Management, Point to Point Movement, Trading

name: Save the President: The Odd-Ball Scenario
description:
Small expansion to Save the President. Bag contains additional rules, cards and data sheets.

Expands:

Save the President
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Spies/Secret Agents

name: Aventuras HerÃ³icas: A RevelaÃ§Ã£o da Princesa / O Encontro com Kaleb
description:
Expansion featuring two new adventures for "Aventuras Heróicas", in nine scenarios. The princess, who was rescued in the end of the base game, joins the party. This time they must destroy Kaleb and his minions.

Expands:

Aventuras HerÃ³icas
categories: Adventure, Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Exploration, Fantasy, Fighting, Miniatures
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: Murderless Mysteries: Arch Villains Anonymous
description:
This is a mystery party game, but NOT a murder mystery.

First in a series called "Murderless Mysteries", that claim the following difference from other mystery party games:
·There is no murder, the crime to be solved is non-violent.
·An unlimited number of party guests can participate.
·The same game can be played again with a different solution.
·No one, including the host and even the culprit, can ever be sure of who dunnit, until it is revealed at the end of the game.

There are 6 main characters who are encouraged to dress in costume but not required, plus a game leader. But other guests at the party can ask questions and vote on who they think did it.

The six main characters in this story are members of a club similar to Alcoholics Anonymous, but they've sworn off evil-doings:
Hagatha Grub—The Activities Director is a wicked old witch who cackles often, sometimes for no apparent reason. Hunched shoulders under black clothing complete with pointy hat, she frequently pets her only friend, her cat.

Professor Trixie Gimmick—The Club's Technical Administrator who runs the club website is an ultimate techo-geek. She prefers machines over people and plays with gadgets all the time, getting a little annoyed when people interrupt her work to talk to her.

Vanessa Van Avarice—The club Secretary is a beautiful vamp, vain, ruthless and very greedy. She flirts with all the men and is catty to all the women.

Captain Brutus LeCad— Would you trust a former pirate as Club Treasurer?

Morley Krupt—A former gangster makes a great Security Officer.

Barnaby Underwood—The club Vice President is a stereotypical villain from melodramas. He constantly twirls his large black mustache and has an evil laugh. He doesn't understand why everyone yells "boo" every time his name is spoken.
categories: Deduction, Humor, Mafia, Murder/Mystery, Party Game, Pirates

name: The Fall Guy
description: Roll the dice and move around the board. Be the first player to capture the bail jumper and have all four stunt cards face up.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Plott: Adventures in Space
description:
Each player has five, different sized, space ships to place within his radar grid. The players take turns placing volleys of five numbered marking pins on their blank radar grids, attempting to locate and thereby destroy their opponents space fleet.

Essentially, this game has the same game play as the well known game "Battleship", but it also permits deployment along the diagonal.

name: Dick Tracy Playing Card Game
description:
A simple but original card game - the goal is to get a hand which is just Dick Tracy and 4 Jewels. There are only 3 card types, Dick Tracy, Jewels, and Thugs. Each turn you can discard Jewels, Dick Tracy, or Thug WITH Dick Tracy, as many times as you like - filling your hand back to 5 at the end of the turn. If you only have Thugs you show your hand and discard one card.

Going out is 30 points. Other players are penalized for each thug in their hand not canceled by a Dick Tracy, and rewarded for each Jewel. The game is to 100.

name: Prism Quest
description:
A fantasy game employing dice, code books, code pads and more than 150 playing cards. Players try to deduce each other's hidden sequence of colors using cards and yes/no responses.

The game is produced from 100% environmentally sound material, such as recycled paper and soy ink.
mechanics: Communication Limits, Deduction, Dice Rolling, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: View-Master 3-D Trivia Quiz
description:
The die is rolled to determine the question category and the corresponding View Master reel.

The 3-d picture in that reel and the the challenging question about what you see in the picture. Answer correctly ..and move one step closer to entering the View Master 3-D Trivia Quiz Winner's Circle
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: The Duel
description:
A miniatures based dueling game.

From the back cover:

This book includes full rules for the Elven fighting style of SHA-DAK Kir. Players can create characters and duel together in order to improve their honor and nobility.

name: Bethump'd with History
description:
From their website:

TO PLAY... Players advance through 2,000 years of history by correctly answering questions and landing on all letters of a chosen Game Word. Be Forewarned: the Action & Opportunity spaces on the board will determine if you are a tyrant or a true humanitarian! Be the first player to land on all letters of the Game Word and reach Utopia to win!

name: Mega Meal
description:
"6 Cheeseburgers, 2 Salads, 1 Ketchup, 7 Milkshakes". Ketchup King is crowded with people! Can you memorize all the orders?

Memory-type game which is different in that the orders are only read to the other players, but not shown. Orders consists of 5 to 9 different cards, each with type and quantity.

name: Gladiator: Men vs. Animals
description:
The floor of the Colosseum (sic) had been divided into two almost equal halves, separated by a tall wooden wall. On each side of the wall wild animals stalked across the hot sands . . . bears, slinking lions and leopards and the solitary tigers who claimed the dubious honor of being the most dangerous of the beasts to hunt and kill . . . Two teams of men emerged onto the field. At the head of each team three spearmen . . . behind them a pair of swordsmen . . . the last man out of each gate carried a heavy lead mace.

The players control separate teams of six gladiators facing off in separate arenas against four animals.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Simulation

name: Concrete Jungle
description:
A game of counter-terrorist combat on a man-to-man level. Each player controls a team of commandos or terrorists, or each member of a team can be controlled by a separate player. These units may be pre-designed, or custom built by you, with different reaction time, skills, weapons, and body armor. The mechanics of play cover the specialized situations found in this type of combat and are condensed into an easy reference sheet for quick use."
The first game released by BTRC. A modern tactical game of small-unit military and police actions. Each counter represents 1 man or vehicle, each turn is 2 seconds, and each square on the map is 2 meters across.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Square Grid, Team-Based Game

name: Quadriga
description: Each (slave in the stables of the Roman Colosseum) has 4 pieces (horses) in one color. Starting from a base line one attempts to bring all four pieces to a line in neighboring portions (form a Quadriga).

name: Shadow Raven
description:
The Object of the Game is to beat your opponent(s) by doing one of two things: destroy his (their) home base(s) by depleting his (their) card library or by winning and claiming five different battle cards.

Interesting sci-fi card game, with seven types of cards: Character, Weapon, Vehicle, Familiar, Action, Battle and Energy. Shadow Raven CCG (combat card game) was designed, I believe, as a true CCG. However only 99 card 'starter' decks were produced. The game is likely to remain non-collectible. Each player needs a deck of his/her own.

name: Touch
description:
Touch, Parker Brothers' game of palmistry.

"Maxine Lucille Fiel has studied scientific hand reading and palmistry for 15 years . . . Maxine claims that the hand is like a graph that reflects the emotional and physical changes in the body.

Touch is intended as a group game for parties or other gatherings. It can, however, be played solitaire since it is basically a detailed guide to palm reading and analysis."

The game includes a set of oversized cards illustrating different categories of markings on the hand and a pad of Profile Sheets for recording which markings appear on a player's hand. The personality characteristic for each type of marking is listed in the game booklet.

The brief rules suggest that players break into groups and work on figuring out the what markings appear on their hands. Once these have been marked down on profile sheets, all of the sheets are gathered and the interpretations are read from the game booklet. The rules suggest that you read the analysis aloud and let your friends try to guess who is being described.

name: Bowlo
description:
The card bowling game is scored exactly as in the regular rules of bowling and playing technique is based on official bowling rules.

Typical bowling score sheets are included.

Ten "frames" are played. High score wins.

Players are dealt a hand of five Bowlo cards.

The deck consists of 54 cards:
18 Ball cards.
12 number 1 Pin cards.
12 number 2 Pin cards.
12 number 3 Pin cards.

Any number of these five cards may be discarded and new cards called for to retain a total of five cards, which every player must hold in order to score.

Should the original five cards held total 10 points a "strike" is called.

After a second hand or a draw, should a 10 be scored, a "spare" is credited.

An "error" is scored for any player who scores less than 10 "Pins" in two hands (or draws).

A "bust" (zero points) is scored when a player has a hand totaling more than 10 "Pins."

name: Silver Cup Sailboat Racing Game
description: A simple sailboat racing game where the players race along a track around the board. Movement is governed by a spinner. Players may be confronted with trivia questions (regarding sailing) during the game - a correct answer moves a boat forward and an incorrect answer moves a boat backward. Additional cards are drawn during the game which provide further information regarding sailing.

name: The Story of the U.S. Air Force
description:
A Landmark Game based on volume 89 in the Landmark children's book series by Random House. For Ages 9 - 15

The game is a race starting from ground level to see who can be the first into orbit. The players start off with balloons and as they climb upwards various historical aircraft become available (including the Wright Flyer, Curtis Jenny, Spirit of St. Louis, P-51, F-104, and X-15). The higher the altitude reached, the more advanced the aircraft that may be acquired.

The game features colorful components with an interesting gimmick or two - for instance, the spinners are part of a box insert depicting an aircraft control panel, and the players use a miniature compass to try and get a correct reading on a radar screen box.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Children's Game, Novel-based, Racing

name: The Improv Comedy Game
description: The Improv Comedy Game is based on the TV show and actual comedy club, The Improv. It tests your ability to make your friends laugh through various actions and jokes. The game contains 4 booklets, one each of "Gags", "Improvs", Groans," and "Cracks", which are used for each player's turn. Players move around a board that is encased in the game box, using plastic pawns. One accumulates points by successfully getting the other players to laugh at the jokes one performs, and can lose points by landing on spaces such as "heckler funnier than you," "audience speaks no English," and "steal material". There is a pegboard in the center of the game board to keep track of each player's score; players move their pegs point by point from "beginner" to "star", and the first person to become a star is the winner of the game. The equipment included is listed in the rules as follows: "12 pawns, 4 hilarious comedy booklets, 3 colored dice, 1 timer, 1 game board/score board, 0 Mercedes convertibles
categories: Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game

name: Battle Grid
description:
From the game box.

"Close Quarters Combat Board Game"

"Victor or vanquished. Which will you be?"

"Since the dawn of civilization, mysterious forces have plucked the ancient armies from their savage battlefields, and placed them on the Battle Grid of eternity. Caught in a maelstrom of space and time, they fight countless battles with the enemies from many famous conflicts: The Hundred Years War, French Revolution, American Revolution, Civil War, World War I and others. Surviving armies savor victory, while the defeated rise again to oppose them. There are battles to be won. Are you ready for more?"

"Battle Grid uses the Skirmish Combat System to resolve close quarters battle. Each player controls a squad of soldiers on the battlefield. All troop commands are resolved by dice rolls, with the special abilities of each army playing an important strategic role in the conflict."

"Object of the Game: Eliminate all of your opponent's soldiers in close quarters, skirmish combat."
categories: American Civil War, American Revolutionary War, Ancient, Dice, Fighting, Medieval, Modern Warfare, Wargame, World War I, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: VCR Dogfight
description: VCR Dogfight is an exciting World War II era interactive video combat game for two intrepid players. You fly your aircraft around the gameboard in a snarling dogfight to gain advantage over your hapless opponent. When guns are fired, view actual World War II dogfight footage to see if you succeed with a hit, or perish in a blaze of your opponent's ammunition."
categories: Aviation / Flight, Wargame, World War II

name: Photo Trivia: MGM Movies Game
description:
107 Photos, 64 Questions & Answers. For travel and party fun! Look at the photos and answer the questions.

Object: Players try to win by looking at the photo and correctly answering a question on each card. The player who collects the most cards is the winner.

name: The Game of Hollywood Stars
description:
Become A Star

Players start as an Extra in Hollywood, U.S.A. and make their way through four tracks of their Hollywood career from Extra to Bit Player to Feature Player and finally, Star.

On the way players try to accumulate money and property from Station Wagons to Speedboats and Academy Awards.

Variation on dice rolls prompt players to read from The Hollywood News.

Winner is the player to win both an Academy Award and have $12,000 in property.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Look at the Schmuck on that Camel
description: Yiddish Trivia Game. Look at the Schmuck on that Camel is a game of over 100 Yiddishisms with 400+ definitions, give or take a little. Participants are asked to logically determine whether a Yiddish word is defined correctly. The game evidently contained a taped performance, music, and comedy cards all based on old Yiddish jokes. The game was the concept of and was written by Wilbur Pierce.

name: Brunete
description:
Brunete is a wargame about the historical points of view that simulates the confrontations between the Republican and National forces that fought in July 1937 in the battle of Brunete during the Spanish Civil War.
Brunete is the first big battle of the Spanish Civil War.
Components:
-Map of 60 x 45 cms.
-288 counters
-Booklet rules in Spanish
-1 dice

name: Casinopoly
description:
Play either as a casino board game or as an add on for board games such as Monopoly. Adds another layer to such a game.
---
Casinopoly: The Casino Party Board Game
Viva Las Vegas! And Atlantic City, too! With Casinopoly, players can play a casino party game or create an add-on feature that's compatible with "the most popular real estate trading board games." The board just happens to fit snugly into the center of a Monopoly board, and, whether you're landing on Boardwalk or cruising the Strip, Casinopoly's easy dice versions of four casino classics provide plenty of action. Played on its own, the game moves faster than the B&O Railroad: Land on roulette and roll the special die showing either red or black; slots dice roll to reveal a combo of cherries, lemons, and bells; toss the two card-faced blackjack bones to hit 21; or attempt to shake 7 or 11 with the regular craps dice. Should high rollers want to move from the Belaggio to Baltic Avenue, the rule sheet explains how to incorporate the games into a round of Monopoly. Casinopoly lets players go from starvin' to Marvin (Gardens, that is) with a roll of the dice.

name: Time Travelers
description:
The object of the game is to travel in time, back into different periods in the past or forward into some periods of time in the future in order to collect souvenir items from each of the 12 periods.
Components: 1 gameboard, 6 playing tokens, 1 sand-timer, 36 souvenir cards, 24 bad-luck cards, 12 time cards, 12 flight cards and two dice.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: O Alquimista
description:
Translated from the box: "A young shepherd dreamed of a treasure hidden in the Pyramids of Egypt. He decided to follow the dream and, in the quest for his Personal Legend, faced great mysteries. The lessons of that journey are in this exciting game."

Based on the book by Paulo Coelho.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Sportac
description: A simple representation of an athletics meeting. Lots of different events are portrayed. Players compete mainly by rolling dice.

name: Eurocracy
description:
This seems to be an educational game about European politics. It has a clear relationship to Monopoly.

From the manual:

Eurocracy is the game about democracy in Europe.
In the game the twelve member states of the European Community are fully integrated. There is just one state with one government and one parliament. According to their size, the member states are represented on the game board with one to four cities and/or regions. The flags symbolize the states to which cities and regions belong.
Players are political parties competing for power. Each party is supported by two social groups. The players go with their playing piece as party leader on a continuous through Europe. By winning elections in cities they obtain Members of the European Parliament. Cities may be exchanged on a voluntary basis. Players in control of all cities of a member state are entitled to European Ministers each time they pass Brussels. The first player to form his or her government of 12 Ministers wins the game and is proclaimed European Prime Minister, provided that he enjoys sufficient support in the European Parliament.

name: Air Aces
description:
An early set of air combat miniatures rules for recreating plane to plane combat in World War II, for two or more players. The designer acknowledges that the game does not use a defined time and space scale, but is instead intended to demonstrate the "relative capabilities" of the various aircraft. The rules were designed for use with 1/100 to 1/365 scale models. Game statistics are given for 8 famous fighter aircraft.

According to the author's introduction, he had worked on the game design since 1967. In the early seventies, the game was used by Spartan International at competitive events, and the game was printed in the Spartan Journal in 1972. One interesting note in the introduction: "When Lou Zocchi saw this game he flipped! He had been working on the same dimensional problems for years, but to no avail. He quickly adopted the 'break-throughs' offered by this game to use in one of his own."
categories: Aviation / Flight, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: The Circus Comes to Town
description:
From the box:

We are bringing an exciting Circus to town. We work together as a team to give the audience the best show we can. This game was inspired by the world famous Cirque du Soleil that features magnificent, daring performances by human beings as well as wonderful humor and skills by Clowns. Animals are included in this game, but since it is your Circus, you can put on your own show with or without them.

Each player spins to see what moves are to be made. Maybe you move the Acrobat along the spotlight spaces. Or maybe the High Wire artist. Or maybe danger looms on the Trapeze and a Safety Net is needed. Can we guide the Performers from Start to Finish without taking a Fall? The risks are great, the moves tricky. The results are very satisfying.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Untrivia
description:
From the box:

A question and answer game with two special features. First, the questions are practical, not trivial. Expect many hours of enjoyable conversation about topics such as Child-rearing, Gardening, Everyday Law, Travel, Health, Cooking, Car & Home Care, etc. Secondly, UNTRIVIA is co-operative. Players share ideas, discuss the possible answers & decide on the best one to go for. A snakes and ladders type of board provides some pitfalls & pleasant surprises.

name: Hugs & Tickles
description:
From the box:

Help everyone from Mom & Dad to Granny & Grandpa have a Great Day and not get caught by The Blues. Pass on a hug. Make others laugh with goofy faces. Tell someone what you like about him or her, dance, sing together, and share a joke... Feel-Good Cards have lots of things to do to chase away The Blues. But watch out for those old Blues; they can sneak up on you very quickly. You can personalize this game's supplies by adding various books & music of your own. Some suggestions are included.

name: Cup Winner
description:
The board is set up as a football pitch with numbers 1-11 on the pitch and 3 trophies to one side.
The object of the game is to win as many trophies as possible.

Each turn the players alternate and roll 2 die and then can cover the appropriate number on the pitch with a counter, or place 1 counter on a space of one of the numbers rolled.
If no numbers are available you forfeit that go.
A double six allows you to cover a trophy, but only if you already have position 9 covered on the field.
Players may opt to keep a six thrown and only use the other die. They will then only use 1 die for future throws until they throw another 6 and win a trophy. They can then throw both die on their subsequent turns.

name: The Pearly Gates
description: Players take on the roles of Television Evangelists. Each player rolls dice and moves up the game track following any special instructions they might encounter along the way. Some things make money for your ministry usually by receiving donations from your followers. Some things cost your ministry money, like ending up in a motel room with another player. The object of the game is to make the most money for your ministry by the time you reach the Pearly Gates. And maybe get a nice tan along the way.
categories: Humor, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Religious

name: Gibberish
description:
Players have to play their cards to the board in such an order that they would form a reasonable sentence. If anyone plays such a card that it turns the sentence unreasonable you could challenge that particular play. The player that played that card must now tell you what the sentence means. These clever explanation/context/twists are where the fun starts. The player will now have to turn that unreasonable sentence into a reasonable one by describing some impossible situation where this particular sentence would make sense. After the explanation others have to vote if the explanation is reasonable enough for the interpreter to get points.

There are a couple of variations to the game, like playing a blind card, and certain actions allowing a player to place a card leaving a gap in between the sentence (in general, more difficult to fill than the usual sequence)

Contents:

U Board game in 6 interlocking parts
Roulette
Cards containing words or short sentences

name: A Box of Silly Word Games
description:
A Box of Silly Word Games is a box of twenty-five word games. Many are parlor games, very suitable for the driver and all passengers in a car to play on a road trip. A few require pencil and paper.

[from the box]
25 FANTASTIC, extraordinarily fun, quick-to-play games for the whole family!

Grab one of the 25 Silly Word Game Cards, gather a couple of friends and you're ready for some quick brain teasing fun! Each card contains quick, clear instructions explaining how to play one word game. Using your quick thinking clever mind, a pencil, pad, die or timer, play until one of you has won! Then grab another card and play again! Great for home, travel, camp, sleep overs & parties!

name: Wacky Wigwam
description: Try to hide your ducks under wigwams. Only one duck under each wigwam. Each turn you spin for the number of wigwams you can uncover - you then can move that number of wigwams on top of your ducks - but you have to remember which wigwams contain your ducks, because you don't want to uncover those.
publishers: Denys Fisher Toys, Parker Brothers, Schmidt Spiele

name: Willie Go Boom
description:
(From the instructions:)

Willie's going to pop, but we don't know when.

How many pumps will it take to make him blow?

If you make Willie's TOP go POP, you win!

(Willie is mechanism that players inflate. When it gets beyond a certain point a Nerf ball is fired in the air.)

name: å¸æ¿å® (Magistrate)
description:
Complexity level 8 on Tsukuda's 1-6 scale (1=easiest).. Um, apparently that rating scale goes to 8. At any rate, this game is complex.

Game length is stated on the box as 4-25 hours, and is strategic in nature.

Based on and inspired by Mayumura Taku's 'hard science fiction' novelette and novel series whose name is "Shiseikan". This is an attempt, according to the designer, to make what he considers a 'true science fiction game', instead of the usual robot-anime SF games released in Japan before then, which he considered to not have as much variety ('items'). "Shiseikan" is a kind of colonial administrator who must control balance among colony, native aliens, and army. This game covers a original episode on planet Roseia. This game must be played with 4 people who each is Shiseikan, colony, natives, and army. Everyone has very different ability and purpose in the game. Very advanced game at that date. Very innovative and truly original work.

name: Giant Gorg
description:
Complexity level 2 on Tsukada's 1-6 scale (1=easiest)

"The Game of Ground fighting in Giant Gorg"

A card-based science-fiction mecha game based off the anime. The game includes 300 cards. The cards are used for almost everything; terrain, movement, characters, mechs, and so on. The only other item used in the game is a 6-sided die.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Collegiate Crew
description:
Collegiate Crew loosely simulates a collegiate crew event between 2-6 colleges, consisting of Freshman, JV, and Varsity races. Event cards are used to give players special abilities to use during the race, and players are given the chance to choose their stroke rate and change their stroke rate once during the race, with higher rates increasing the possibility of moving faster but lowering the expected value.

Winners of Freshman and JV races earn extra cards for the Varsity race while race losers give up a card. Play all 3 races to experience the entire game. The object is to win the Varsity race. As in the real world, nothing else matters except who wins the varsity.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Grabung im Tal der KÃ¶nige
description: This game is about expeditions. You bid for the right to be the first one to look for some old treasures in every round. If you find something nice you get money for it. If you do not find something you wasted the money you bid. Three dice make the decision if you find something.If you find something you also get points. The player who earns 12 points first wins.

name: Alphabet Soup
description: Actually, it's a "spin-and-move" game instead of "roll and move", but that is essentially the same thing. Players take turns moving around the board, drawing letter tiles from the face-down pile in the center of the board (the "alphabet soup"). If they draw a letter that can be used to spell the name of one of the six animals on the board, and that letter hasn't already been placed on the board, they place the tile in the appropriate spot. If they place the tile that completes the name, they take the name off the board and put it in front of them. The first player to have three different animal names in front of them wins.

name: Farm n' Country Trivia
description:
Each players tries to correctly answers as many questions as possible in order to be the first player to advance around the board to the "WINNER" box.

It's a fairly straightforward "land on a square, answer a question" game, involving questions based on agriculture.

name: Friedensreiter
description: Westfaelischer Friede in Germany. The war is over and there are a many messages to transport. You get a horse and your journey begins. The better your horse is the more dice you can roll. There are also action cards.

name: Tabula
description: Another nice little wooden board game from Pro Ligno.

name: Treasure Ahoy!
description:
Fairly straightforward children's game with a pirate theme. The contents consist of a board depicting a tropical island, four colored pawns, a die, and a set of cards representing various adventure equipment such as compass, map, cutlass, etc. Four of the cards depict treasure.

At the start of the game, the four treasures and six other cards are shuffled together and placed on each of the ten 'hiding places' on the island, and an additional three cards are dealt to each player. On his turn, the player can choose to either discard a card and draw a replacement, or roll the die and move his pawn. He can only move onto a blue hiding place by discarding the appropriate equipment card for that location, but doing so entitles him to look at the card placed there and, if desired, exchange it with one from his hand. However, to take away a treasure card an additional piece of equipment must be expended; a key for a treasure chest, a spade for buried treasure. At the end of his turn, the player refreshes back to three cards.

Once a treasure card has been procured, the player will need to get it back aboard his ship. To do this he must return to his start square and play a boat card to get the booty aboard. Until he achieves this, he runs the risk of losing it to another player landing on the same square and playing a 'plunder' card. The game ends when all four treasures have been secured offshore and the player who has the most is the winner.

name: TV Trivia Game
description: From the box: If you love "Lucy", like to hoist a few at Cheers, visit the West Wing, get admitted to the ER or just love a show about nothing, this is the game for you. Packed with behind the scenes info on your favorite shows and stars. Designed for the couch potato or casual viewer. This game is top of the ratings.

name: Alzabandiera
description:
From the Homepage of Kidult Game:

A "geographical" challenge with questions and answers, and a pizzico (smidgen) of strategy that always fits. Choose your flag and challenge your friends, if they accept you’ll score too, but if they refuse you will have to answer! A great chance to gain a high score, or to make a low one!
Sixty flags to find out how large the world is!

Download the game pdf file at the Kidult Homepage.

name: Dynasty
description:
Very rare role-playing game of politics, diplomacy and military strength in China. Players take social positions within an agricultural society.
